clusters.title: Breaking down Israel's decision to strike inside Qatar
clusters.neutral_headline: Israel Strikes Qatar, Targeting Hamas Leaders

items.title: Breaking down Israel's decision to strike inside Qatar
items.standfirst: The Israeli military carried out strikes on residential buildings in Qatar on Tuesday. Israel said it was targeting senior Hamas leadership, but Hamas claims only 5 lower-level officials were killed. Former CBS news correspondent Dan Raviv has analysis.
items.content: The Israeli military carried out strikes on residential buildings in Qatar on Tuesday. Israel said it was targeting senior Hamas leadership, but Hamas claims only 5 lower-level officials were killed. Former CBS news correspondent Dan Raviv has analysis.

items.title: Trump says US warned Qatar of impending Israel strike but were ‘too late to stop the attack’ – Middle East crisis live
items.standfirst: Qatar says attack is ‘serious escalation’ as world leaders say strike on Doha risks efforts for a ceasefire in Gaza; Hamas says six people were killed in attackIsrael launches airstrikes against top Hamas members in Qatar for Gaza ceasefire talksDan Sabbagh is the Guardian’s defence and security editorFifty-one Israeli arms makers and the US defence giant behind the F-35 fighters used to bomb Gaza are among the 1,600 exhibitors at the biennial DSEI trade show that begins in London’s Docklands on Tuesday. Continue reading...

Continue reading...

items.title: Hamas says no senior leadership killed by Israel's strike in Qatar
items.standfirst: Israel says it was targeting senior Hamas leadership when it launched a strike on a series of buildings in Doha, the capital city of Qatar, Tuesday. CBS News ' Leigh Kiniry reports and Aaron Navarro has more from the White House.
items.content: Israel says it was targeting senior Hamas leadership when it launched a strike on a series of buildings in Doha, the capital city of Qatar, Tuesday. CBS News ' Leigh Kiniry reports and Aaron Navarro has more from the White House.

items.title: Trump says strike on Doha 'does not advance Israel or America's goals'
items.standfirst: The US president says he feels "very badly" about the location of the attack and calls Qatar a "close ally".
items.content: The US president says he feels "very badly" about the location of the attack and calls Qatar a "close ally".

items.title: When did the White House learn of Israel's strikes on Doha?
items.standfirst: Israel carried out military strikes against senior Hamas leaders in the Qatari capital of Doha on Tuesday. CBS News senior national security correspondent Charlie D'Agata has more on what the U.S. knew about the attack.
items.content: Israel carried out military strikes against senior Hamas leaders in the Qatari capital of Doha on Tuesday. CBS News senior national security correspondent Charlie D'Agata has more on what the U.S. knew about the attack.

items.title: What do we know about the strike?
items.standfirst: Israel carried out a strike on senior Hamas leaders in Qatar's capital Doha on Tuesday.
items.content: Israel carried out a strike on senior Hamas leaders in Qatar's capital Doha on Tuesday.

items.title: Israel Targets Hamas Leadership in Doha Strikes
Hamas leaders survive Israeli strike on Qatar; US denies involvement
items.standfirst: The United States claims it was not involved in the Israeli attack targeting top Hamas officials in Doha.
items.content: The United States claims it was not involved in the Israeli attack targeting top Hamas officials in Doha.

items.title: 'Cracks are showing' in the US-Israel relationship as Israel strikes Doha
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump did not agree with Israel's choice to conduct strikes against Hamas inside US ally Qatar, the White House said Tuesday. While eliminating Hamas was a "worthy goal," a strike in the Qatari capital Doha "does not advance Israel or America's goals," White House Press Secretary Karoline Leavitt told reporters, reading from a statement. FRANCE 24's Noga Tarnopolsky reports from Jerusalem.
items.content: US President Donald Trump did not agree with Israel's choice to conduct strikes against Hamas inside US ally Qatar, the White House said Tuesday. While eliminating Hamas was a "worthy goal," a strike in the Qatari capital Doha "does not advance Israel or America's goals," White House Press Secretary Karoline Leavitt told reporters, reading from a statement. FRANCE 24's Noga Tarnopolsky reports from Jerusalem.

items.title: Netanyahu claims Doha strike can lead to peace in Gaza
items.standfirst: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said the strike on Hamas offices in Qatar could “open the door to an end of the war” in Gaza. According to Hamas, five of its members were killed in the attack but the leaders targeted by Israel survived.
items.content: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said the strike on Hamas offices in Qatar could “open the door to an end of the war” in Gaza. According to Hamas, five of its members were killed in the attack but the leaders targeted by Israel survived.

items.title: Israel Strikes Hamas In Qatar
items.standfirst: Hamas says six people killed in air strike but its leadership team survived.
items.content: Hamas says six people killed in air strike but its leadership team survived.

items.title: Hamas claims leadership survived Israeli attack in Doha, but confirms six deaths
items.standfirst: Meanwhile, the White House says the Israeli strike "does not advance Israel or America's goals".
items.content: Meanwhile, the White House says the Israeli strike "does not advance Israel or America's goals".

items.title: Israel launches attack on Hamas in Qatar
items.standfirst: US issues rare censure after six killed in strikes on Gulf state
items.content: US issues rare censure after six killed in strikes on Gulf state

items.title: Bowen: Diplomacy in ruins after Israel strikes Hamas leaders in Qatar
items.standfirst: The Doha attack signals that Benjamin Netanyahu will press forward hard on all fronts, writes Jeremy Bowen.
items.content: The Doha attack signals that Benjamin Netanyahu will press forward hard on all fronts, writes Jeremy Bowen.

items.title: Israel launches airstrikes against top Hamas members in Qatar for Gaza ceasefire talks
items.standfirst: Hamas says six were killed but its leadership survived the attack, which the US says ‘does not advance Israel or America’s goals’Middle East crisis – live updatesIsrael has launched a strike on Hamas officials meeting in Qatar’s capital, Doha, reportedly including the group’s chief ceasefire negotiator, in an attack the White House said “does not advance Israel or America’s goals”.Hamas said six people had been killed, including the son of its exiled Gaza chief, Khalil al-Hayya. It said its top leadership, including the negotiations team, had survived. Continue reading...
items.content: Hamas says six were killed but its leadership survived the attack, which the US says ‘does not advance Israel or America’s goals’Middle East crisis – live updatesIsrael has launched a strike on Hamas officials meeting in Qatar’s capital, Doha, reportedly including the group’s chief ceasefire negotiator, in an attack the White House said “does not advance Israel or America’s goals”.Hamas said six people had been killed, including the son of its exiled Gaza chief, Khalil al-Hayya. It said its top leadership, including the negotiations team, had survived. Continue reading...

items.title: Israel attacks Hamas leadership in Qatar: All to know
items.standfirst: Multiple explosions were heard in Qatar's capital Doha, in an attack targeting Hamas leaders including Khalil al-Hayya.
items.content: Multiple explosions were heard in Qatar's capital Doha, in an attack targeting Hamas leaders including Khalil al-Hayya.

items.title: Hamas says six dead in Israeli strike including Qatari security officer
items.standfirst: Hamas said six people were killed in an Israeli strike on the group's compound in Doha on Tuesday, including its top negotiator's son and a Qatari security officer. Three bodyguards and Gaza ceasefire negotiator Khalil al-Hayya's aide and son were all killed in the attack, the group said, affirming "the enemy's failure to assassinate our brothers in the negotiating delegation". FRANCE 24's Olivia Bizot reports.
items.content: Hamas said six people were killed in an Israeli strike on the group's compound in Doha on Tuesday, including its top negotiator's son and a Qatari security officer. Three bodyguards and Gaza ceasefire negotiator Khalil al-Hayya's aide and son were all killed in the attack, the group said, affirming "the enemy's failure to assassinate our brothers in the negotiating delegation". FRANCE 24's Olivia Bizot reports.

items.title: Analysis: Israel leaps over red lines in attack on Qatari capital Doha
items.standfirst: Attack on Hamas leaders in Qatari capital Doha shows Israel will keep escalating if global powers don't stop it.
items.content: Attack on Hamas leaders in Qatari capital Doha shows Israel will keep escalating if global powers don't stop it.

items.content: Al Jazeera’s Virginia Pietromarchi showed us the aftermath of Israel’s 'targeted strike’ in a diplomatic area of Doha.

items.title: Hamas official says leadership survived attack in Doha
items.standfirst: Hamas’s leadership that was targeted in an Israeli attack in Doha has survived but at least two others were killed.
items.content: Hamas’s leadership that was targeted in an Israeli attack in Doha has survived but at least two others were killed.

items.title: Hamas says its leadership survived Israel’s assassination bid in Doha
items.standfirst: In an statement, the group said at least six people were killed in the attack that was intended to derail truce talks.
items.content: In an statement, the group said at least six people were killed in the attack that was intended to derail truce talks.

items.title: Israel strikes Hamas leadership in Qatar, which had been mediating a ceasefire in Gaza
items.standfirst: Israel carried out a strike against Hamas’ senior leadership on Tuesday in Doha, the capital of Qatar, marking a significant escalation in its multifront conflict in the region.
items.content: Israel carried out a strike against Hamas’ senior leadership on Tuesday in Doha, the capital of Qatar, marking a significant escalation in its multifront conflict in the region.

ai_summary: Israel launched strikes on residential buildings in Qatar, targeting Hamas leadership.
Hamas claims only five lower-level officials were killed in the attack.
Trump stated the US warned Qatar but were too late to stop the attack.
The BBC reported on what is known about the strike on senior Hamas leaders.
The White House was asked when they learned of the Israeli strikes on Doha.

clusters.title: Social media ban sparks violent protests in Nepal
clusters.neutral_headline: Nepal Protests Erupt After Social Media Ban

items.title: Social media ban sparks violent protests in Nepal
items.standfirst: In Nepal, the government’s ban of social media apps including Facebook and Instagram sparked violent protests. The prime minister has now resigned and the government revoked the ban. NBC News’ Raf Sanchez reports.
items.content: In Nepal, the government’s ban of social media apps including Facebook and Instagram sparked violent protests. The prime minister has now resigned and the government revoked the ban. NBC News’ Raf Sanchez reports.

items.title: Nepal anti-corruption protests explained
items.standfirst: Protests in Nepal turned deadly after thousands of youngsters marched against the blocking of social media platforms.
items.content: Protests in Nepal turned deadly after thousands of youngsters marched against the blocking of social media platforms.

items.title: Nepali PM forced to step down, parliament torched amid deadly protests
items.standfirst: KP Oli steps down but mass anticorruption protests continue, with government buildings set on fire.
items.content: KP Oli steps down but mass anticorruption protests continue, with government buildings set on fire.

items.title: Nepal parliament set on fire after PM resigns over anti-corruption protests
items.standfirst: KP Sharma Oli steps down amid Nepal's worst unrest in decades, with at least 22 deaths reported in clashes.
items.content: KP Sharma Oli steps down amid Nepal's worst unrest in decades, with at least 22 deaths reported in clashes.

items.title: Nepal's prime minister resigns after deadly protests
items.standfirst: Nepal's Prime Minister KP Sharma Oil resigned Tuesday after deadly protests over the country's social media ban that has since been repealed. CBS News' Shanelle Kaul has the latest.
items.content: Nepal's Prime Minister KP Sharma Oil resigned Tuesday after deadly protests over the country's social media ban that has since been repealed. CBS News' Shanelle Kaul has the latest.

items.title: Nepal: PM resigns after deadly protests
items.standfirst: Protests in Nepal have already left 19 people dead and at least 90 injured, as the unrest entered its second day and Prime Minister KP Sharma Oli resigned from office.
items.content: Protests in Nepal have already left 19 people dead and at least 90 injured, as the unrest entered its second day and Prime Minister KP Sharma Oli resigned from office.

items.title: Nepal prime minister quits after deaths at protests sparked by social media ban
items.standfirst: KP Sharma Oli resigns as police meet protests with deadly force, leaving 19 dead, and federal parliament is set alight Nepal’s prime minister has resigned after some of the worst unrest in decades rocked the country this week, set off by a ban on social media and discontent at political corruption and nepotism.KP Sharma Oli’s resignation came a day after widespread protests were met with deadly force by police, leaving 19 dead and hundreds injured. The spark for the protests was a government ban on 26 prominent social media apps, but escalated into a larger mass movement against corruption among political elites. Continue reading...
items.content: KP Sharma Oli resigns as police meet protests with deadly force, leaving 19 dead, and federal parliament is set alight Nepal’s prime minister has resigned after some of the worst unrest in decades rocked the country this week, set off by a ban on social media and discontent at political corruption and nepotism.KP Sharma Oli’s resignation came a day after widespread protests were met with deadly force by police, leaving 19 dead and hundreds injured. The spark for the protests was a government ban on 26 prominent social media apps, but escalated into a larger mass movement against corruption among political elites. Continue reading...

items.title: Nepal PM resigns after deadly protests triggered by social media ban
items.standfirst: Nepal's prime minister KP Sharma Oli has resigned after violent anti-corruption protests.
items.content: Nepal's prime minister KP Sharma Oli has resigned after violent anti-corruption protests.

items.title: At least 19 killed in ‘gen Z’ protests against Nepal’s social media ban
items.standfirst: Many demonstrators say they are also on the streets over corruption and nepotism they allege is rampant At least 19 people have been killed during protests in Nepal over a government ban on dozens of online platforms including Facebook, Instagram, WhatsApp and X.The government has faced mounting criticism after imposing a ban on 26 prominent social media platforms and messaging apps last week because they had missed a deadline to register under new regulations. Continue reading...
items.content: Many demonstrators say they are also on the streets over corruption and nepotism they allege is rampant At least 19 people have been killed during protests in Nepal over a government ban on dozens of online platforms including Facebook, Instagram, WhatsApp and X.The government has faced mounting criticism after imposing a ban on 26 prominent social media platforms and messaging apps last week because they had missed a deadline to register under new regulations. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Nepal's government banned social media apps, sparking violent protests.
The Prime Minister resigned, and the government revoked the ban.
Protests turned deadly, with at least 22 deaths reported in clashes.
Government buildings were set on fire during the anti-corruption protests.
The ban on social media apps led to widespread unrest in Nepal.

items.content: Elizabeth Tsurkov​, an Israeli and Russian citizen, is now safe at the U.S. Embassy in Iraq, President Trump announced Tuesday.

items.title: Abducted Israeli-Russian researcher Elizabeth Tsurkov freed in Iraq
items.standfirst: A Princeton student "tortured for many months" by Iraqi militia is now in the US embassy, President Trump says.
items.content: A Princeton student "tortured for many months" by Iraqi militia is now in the US embassy, President Trump says.

items.title: Israeli-Russian graduate student freed after 903 days in Hezbollah captivity
items.standfirst: Elizabeth Tsurkov, who entered Iraq to do research for Princeton, had gone missing in Iraq in early 2023Israeli-Russian academic and Princeton student Elizabeth Tsurkov has been released after being kidnapped by Kata’ib Hezbollah and spending more than two years in captivity, Donald Trump said in a post on social media.“I am pleased to report that Elizabeth Tsurkov, a Princeton Student, whose sister is an American Citizen, was just released by Kata’ib Hezbollah (MILITANT Hezbollah), and is now safely in the American Embassy in Iraq after being tortured for many months. I will always fight for JUSTICE, and never give up. HAMAS, RELEASE THE HOSTAGES, NOW!” the US president wrote in a TruthSocial post on Tuesday. Continue reading...
items.content: Elizabeth Tsurkov, who entered Iraq to do research for Princeton, had gone missing in Iraq in early 2023Israeli-Russian academic and Princeton student Elizabeth Tsurkov has been released after being kidnapped by Kata’ib Hezbollah and spending more than two years in captivity, Donald Trump said in a post on social media.“I am pleased to report that Elizabeth Tsurkov, a Princeton Student, whose sister is an American Citizen, was just released by Kata’ib Hezbollah (MILITANT Hezbollah), and is now safely in the American Embassy in Iraq after being tortured for many months. I will always fight for JUSTICE, and never give up. HAMAS, RELEASE THE HOSTAGES, NOW!” the US president wrote in a TruthSocial post on Tuesday. Continue reading...

Tsurkov was held captive for over 900 days in Iraq.
She is now safely in the American Embassy in Iraq.
Trump announced her release on social media.
Tsurkov is an Israeli and Russian citizen.

clusters.title: What's different about the new iPhone Air?
clusters.neutral_headline: Apple Unveils New iPhone 17 Lineup

items.title: What's different about the new iPhone Air?
items.standfirst: Apple unveiled its latest generation of products during its annual launch event in California on Tuesday, including its slimmest iPhone yet. The iPhone 17, AirPods Pro 3 and Apple Watch Series 11 will hit stores on Sept. 19. The tech giant also debuted its new iPhone Air. CNET editor at large Bridget Carey joins "The Daily Report" to discuss.
items.content: Apple unveiled its latest generation of products during its annual launch event in California on Tuesday, including its slimmest iPhone yet. The iPhone 17, AirPods Pro 3 and Apple Watch Series 11 will hit stores on Sept. 19. The tech giant also debuted its new iPhone Air. CNET editor at large Bridget Carey joins "The Daily Report" to discuss.

items.title: Apple has unveiled its iPhone 17 lineup, including the first iPhone Air. Here’s what’s new

The iPhone Air is the thinnest smartphone Apple has made.
The AirPods Pro 3 was also unveiled at the event.

clusters.title: Ethiopia launches Africa's largest hydroelectric dam, sparking Egyptian protest

items.title: Ethiopia launches Africa's largest hydroelectric dam, sparking Egyptian protest
items.standfirst: Standing 170 metres high and stretching nearly 2 km across the Blue Nile, Ethiopia has officially unveiled the largest hydroelectric dam in Africa. While it is expected to supply electricity to millions of Ethiopians, it also risks exacerbating tensions with neighbouring Egypt and Sudan, who are concerned about their water reserves.
items.content: Standing 170 metres high and stretching nearly 2 km across the Blue Nile, Ethiopia has officially unveiled the largest hydroelectric dam in Africa. While it is expected to supply electricity to millions of Ethiopians, it also risks exacerbating tensions with neighbouring Egypt and Sudan, who are concerned about their water reserves.

Continue reading...

items.title: Macron names close ally Lecornu new PM
items.standfirst: French President Emmanuel Macron on Tuesday named armed forces minister and his close ally Sebastien Lecornu as the new prime minister to replace Francois Bayrou as the seventh premier of his mandate. The formal handover of power between Bayrou and Lecornu is due to take place on Wednesday at midday. FRANCE 24's Claire Paccalin reports.

clusters.title: France's new PM tasked with forging consensus on a 2026 budget
clusters.neutral_headline: New French PM Faces Budget Challenges

items.title: France's new PM tasked with forging consensus on a 2026 budget
items.standfirst: French President Emmanuel Macron has picked defence chief Sébastien Lecornu as his new Prime Minsiter a day after François Bayrou was voted out in parliament. The 39-year-old's immediate priority will be to try and forge consensus on a new budget, before forming a government. If this year's budget were to be carried over into next year, France's fiscal deficit, already the highest in the EU, is predicted to widen further.
items.content: French President Emmanuel Macron has picked defence chief Sébastien Lecornu as his new Prime Minsiter a day after François Bayrou was voted out in parliament. The 39-year-old's immediate priority will be to try and forge consensus on a new budget, before forming a government. If this year's budget were to be carried over into next year, France's fiscal deficit, already the highest in the EU, is predicted to widen further.

items.title: Emmanuel Macron appoints his third prime minister in a year
items.standfirst: Sébastien Lecornu, a presidential ally, is tasked with bringing France’s divided parties together to pass a budgetSébastien Lecornu, a close ally of Emmanuel Macron, has been appointed prime minister, tasked with consulting France’s divided political parties to try to find a consensus on the budget.The 39-year-old began his political career in the traditional rightwing party of Nicolas Sarkozy before moving to Macron’s centre in 2017 and is seen as fiercely loyal to the president. Continue reading...

items.title: After Bayrou: What happens now that France has ousted yet another prime minister?
items.standfirst: Another one bites the dust. Prime Minister François Bayrou on Tuesday became the fourth premier in less than two years to submit his resignation after losing a crushing confidence vote in parliament. As President Emmanuel Macron scrambles to find a successor, can France find a way out of its deepening political crisis?
items.content: Another one bites the dust. Prime Minister François Bayrou on Tuesday became the fourth premier in less than two years to submit his resignation after losing a crushing confidence vote in parliament. As President Emmanuel Macron scrambles to find a successor, can France find a way out of its deepening political crisis?

items.title: ‘Resigned to Failure?’ Bayrou’s ‘doomed gamble’ harks back to Macron's 2024 snap elections fallout
items.standfirst: In a dramatic turn that exposed the unraveling of France’s political center, Prime Minister François Bayrou resigned after a humiliating defeat in a no-confidence vote he had called himself. The self-inflicted collapse deepens the crisis engulfing President Emmanuel Macron, now forced to name his seventh prime minister, a sign of growing dysfunction in the Fifth Republic. For deeper insight into the turmoil, Eve Irvine welcomes Olivier Guyottot, Researcher and Professor of Policy at INSEEC Grande École Bordeaux.
items.content: In a dramatic turn that exposed the unraveling of France’s political center, Prime Minister François Bayrou resigned after a humiliating defeat in a no-confidence vote he had called himself. The self-inflicted collapse deepens the crisis engulfing President Emmanuel Macron, now forced to name his seventh prime minister, a sign of growing dysfunction in the Fifth Republic. For deeper insight into the turmoil, Eve Irvine welcomes Olivier Guyottot, Researcher and Professor of Policy at INSEEC Grande École Bordeaux.

clusters.title: Joseph Kony case in The Hague begins with accounts of alleged atrocities
clusters.neutral_headline: ICC Hears War Crimes Case Against Ugandan Rebel Leader

items.title: Joseph Kony case in The Hague begins with accounts of alleged atrocities
items.standfirst: ICC hearing takes place in absence of Ugandan rebel leader accused of murder, rape, torture and sexual slaveryAn international criminal court hearing into charges of war crimes and crimes against humanity against the Ugandan fugitive rebel leader Joseph Kony has begun with accounts of atrocities allegedly committed by his Lord’s Resistance Army.The ICC’s first in-absentia hearing will confirm charges but cannot progress to a trial in Kony’s absence. The warlord faces 39 counts, including murder, rape, sexual slavery, enslavement and torture, allegedly committed in northern Uganda between July 2002 and December 2005.Reuters and Agence France-Presse contributed to this report Continue reading...
items.content: ICC hearing takes place in absence of Ugandan rebel leader accused of murder, rape, torture and sexual slaveryAn international criminal court hearing into charges of war crimes and crimes against humanity against the Ugandan fugitive rebel leader Joseph Kony has begun with accounts of atrocities allegedly committed by his Lord’s Resistance Army.The ICC’s first in-absentia hearing will confirm charges but cannot progress to a trial in Kony’s absence. The warlord faces 39 counts, including murder, rape, sexual slavery, enslavement and torture, allegedly committed in northern Uganda between July 2002 and December 2005.Reuters and Agence France-Presse contributed to this report Continue reading...

items.title: Pigs' heads left outside mosques in Paris region
items.standfirst: At least nine pigs' heads were found outside several mosques in the Paris region on Tuesday, the city's police chief said -- an incident that has sparked alarm over rising anti-Muslim hatred. FRANCE 24's Daniel Quinlan reports.

items.title: At least nine pigs’ heads found outside mosques in Paris region
items.standfirst: Police do not rule out possibility of finding more as incidents raise alarm over increase of anti-Muslim hatred At least nine pigs’ heads were found outside several mosques in the Paris region on Tuesday, the city’s police chief said, prompting alarm over rising anti-Muslim hatred.“Pigs’ heads have been left in front of certain mosques ... Four in Paris and five in the inner suburbs,” Laurent Nuñez told a press conference, adding that officers were not “ruling out the possibility of finding more”. Continue reading...
items.content: Police do not rule out possibility of finding more as incidents raise alarm over increase of anti-Muslim hatred At least nine pigs’ heads were found outside several mosques in the Paris region on Tuesday, the city’s police chief said, prompting alarm over rising anti-Muslim hatred.“Pigs’ heads have been left in front of certain mosques ... Four in Paris and five in the inner suburbs,” Laurent Nuñez told a press conference, adding that officers were not “ruling out the possibility of finding more”. Continue reading...

The company had rolled out a new minimalist logo.

clusters.neutral_headline: Starmer condemns Israel’s airstrike on Qatar as No 10 denies prior knowledge of attack

items.title: Starmer condemns Israel’s airstrike on Qatar as No 10 denies prior knowledge of attack
items.standfirst: ‘Immediate ceasefire, the release of hostages and a huge surge in aid into Gaza’ only route to peace, says PMKeir Starmer has condemned Israel’s strike on Qatar before a meeting with the Israeli president in London on Wednesday.The UK prime minister said the military strike, which targeted Hamas leaders stationed in Doha, was a violation of Qatar’s sovereignty and risked “further escalation across the region”. Continue reading...
items.content: ‘Immediate ceasefire, the release of hostages and a huge surge in aid into Gaza’ only route to peace, says PMKeir Starmer has condemned Israel’s strike on Qatar before a meeting with the Israeli president in London on Wednesday.The UK prime minister said the military strike, which targeted Hamas leaders stationed in Doha, was a violation of Qatar’s sovereignty and risked “further escalation across the region”. Continue reading...

items.title: EU leaders condemn Israeli attack on Hamas in Doha, White House calls strike 'unfortunate'
items.standfirst: Israel launched an airstrike against the leaders of Hamas in Qatar on Tuesday as they gathered to consider a US proposal for a ceasefire in the Gaza Strip, drawing condemnation from its allies in Europe and a rare rebuke from the Trump administration. UN chief Antonio Guterres said the Israeli attack was a "flagrant violation" of Qatari sovereignty.
items.content: Israel launched an airstrike against the leaders of Hamas in Qatar on Tuesday as they gathered to consider a US proposal for a ceasefire in the Gaza Strip, drawing condemnation from its allies in Europe and a rare rebuke from the Trump administration. UN chief Antonio Guterres said the Israeli attack was a "flagrant violation" of Qatari sovereignty.

ai_summary: Keir Starmer condemned Israel's strike on Qatar.
The strike targeted Hamas leaders stationed in Doha.
The UK Prime Minister said the strike violated Qatar's sovereignty.
EU leaders also condemned the Israeli attack.
The White House called the strike "unfortunate".

clusters.title: Israeli military orders all Gaza City residents to evacuate ahead of ground assault
clusters.neutral_headline: Israeli military orders all Gaza City residents to evacuate ahead of ground assault

items.title: Israeli military orders all Gaza City residents to evacuate ahead of ground assault
items.standfirst: Prime Minister Netanyahu says recent strikes on high-rises are "only the beginning of the main, intensive operation" to capture the city.
items.content: Prime Minister Netanyahu says recent strikes on high-rises are "only the beginning of the main, intensive operation" to capture the city.

items.title: Israel orders evacuation of Gaza City
items.standfirst: Benjamin Netanyahu has argued assault is needed to break Hamas
items.content: Benjamin Netanyahu has argued assault is needed to break Hamas

ai_summary: The Israeli military ordered Gaza City residents to evacuate.
The evacuation order precedes a planned ground assault.
Prime Minister Netanyahu said strikes are the beginning of the operation.
The operation aims to capture the city of Gaza.
The Financial Times also reported on the evacuation order.

clusters.title: Video shows purported drone strike on Gaza aid flotilla vessel
clusters.neutral_headline: Video shows purported drone strike on Gaza aid flotilla vessel

items.title: Video shows purported drone strike on Gaza aid flotilla vessel
items.standfirst: Video captured the purported drone strike on a Gaza aid flotilla in Tunisian waters, according to organizers for the vessel. Tunisian authorities said the explosion came from inside the vessel, rejecting the claim it was hit off the country’s coast.
items.content: Video captured the purported drone strike on a Gaza aid flotilla in Tunisian waters, according to organizers for the vessel. Tunisian authorities said the explosion came from inside the vessel, rejecting the claim it was hit off the country’s coast.

items.title: Greta Thunberg's Gaza flotilla hit by drone, organisers claim
items.standfirst: Global Sumud Flotilla says a fire was started but Tunisian authorities deny that a drone was involved.
items.content: Global Sumud Flotilla says a fire was started but Tunisian authorities deny that a drone was involved.

ai_summary: Video shows a purported drone strike on a Gaza aid flotilla.
The strike occurred in Tunisian waters, according to organizers.
Tunisian authorities claim the explosion came from inside the vessel.
The Global Sumud Flotilla claims a fire was started by a drone.
The BBC also reported on the incident.
